TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesdays: The "Everything's Shaping Up" Edition

Articles.Content:
1) How are you dealing with things like boosters that would in theory be recoverable, but which usually despawn before you would get a chance to revoer them (assuming you're dealing with them at all)

2) What potential is there, for better or worse, for contract grinding. For example, if there is a contract to land on the Mun, which will reward you $10,000, is it a contract you can only do once? Can you only do it X number of times? Can you do it any number of times always for $10,000, or can you do it any number of times, but the reward you get back for each repetition of the contract gives you a lower profit as the previous completion?

These are 2 great questions I"d like answered myself.

1) My biggest concern is just that, if something is recovered its refunded. If you notice when you "delete" or "Recover" something, the button is different. If its not broken up, and is on Kerbal you can "Recover" it, instead of just removing or deleting it. I'm assuming if you press the "Recover" button It'll refund the cost of that part to you if at least partially (I'd be ok if the fuel wasn't refunded since it was used up and all).

2) I'm worried about this "Grinding" feature as well. I don't see why a contract should allow you to do it infinite times for the same payout, unless it was to put an RP element into it. For instance. "Put a probe orbiting the Mun at 20km for an independent business." or "Independent Business X wishes for you to collect Mun rocks, bring some back from the Mun Highlands." If I had several missions like that which makes it understandable then I'd be ok with constant/same or slightly fluctuating payouts, since you can mark it off as different companies or businesses making the contract, and not just all from the same source.

Bob (Calisker): Getting ready for First Contract to go live soon but in the meantime, was really stoked to see this Le Monde feature on Kerbal Space Program go live: http://goo.gl/KF4FNb. If you read French, please feel free to let us know what you think, or if youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re like me, use Google Translate to get the gist of it.

Overall very positive. Focuses a lot on the educational possibilities of the game, praises KSP for the fidelity of the simulation (with the only caveat being the "one SOI" thing), and goes into detail about KerbalEDU and Teacher Gaming. The article then goes into a discussion on inductive vs deductive learning, using KSP as an example of the former. The article focuses, as I said, a lot on the educational aspect and how it makes dry physics tangible and understandable to people, and to that end interviews two french teenagers who are really into the game.

All in all, I'd say its another feather in KSPs cap.

Actual mission design hinges on a great many things, almost none of which are properly simulated in KSP. At most, KSP could show things like LOR making a lighter mission, but NASA already had that through careful reasoning and calculations, and LOR depended on a lot of other things too. It teaches orbital rendezvous techniques, but NASA already had those, in part through Buzz Aldrin (his Ph.D. thesis was on orbital rendezvous techniques).

Will this release/feature eventually be made available to the general public? RSS is great and all but this really needs to be what the stock game is.

Think about the advantages of using Kerbals and Kerbol solar system instead of humans and real solar system :

- The game is less hard, more fun

- The pace is quicker (while still very peaceful), more fun

- Kerbonauts are cute, more fun

- Explosions and failures are fun, because it is just Kerbals and they are "born" for that

Now I agree RSS could be an option in the stock game. Actually, many mods (RemoteTech, TAC-LS, Deadly Re-entry...) deserve to be part of the stock game. But Squad has a tiny dev team, and KSP has great modders
